thread.title: Man cycles 150 km across Okanagan for food security in Ukraine
thread.title_full: Man cycles 150 km across Okanagan for food security in Ukraine

author: Logan Lockhart
title: Man cycles 150 km across Okanagan for food security in Ukraine
text:
A now-Kelowna resident recently peddled along Penticton’s iconic Granfondo route in support of feeding families in his home country.
Bohdan Chekerenda, who, along with his family, fled war-torn Ukraine more than three years ago, cycled 150 kilometres to raise funds for “Peremoha (Victory) Bread” on Oct. 11.
The bakery is a registered charity run entirely by volunteers, and has delivered over 2.5 million loaves to Ukrainian families in need since the Russia-Ukraine war began in February 2022.
This marked the third year in a row that Chekerenda has cycled in support of Ukraine.
“Every pedal stroke reminds me that people in Ukraine are enduring far greater hardships,” says Chekerenda. “If my ride inspires even one more person to donate — to feed someone and give them hope — then it’s worth every kilometre.”
It costs Victory Bread just 60 cents to make a loaf, with every dollar raised translating directly into food, non-profit organization Okanagan 4 Ukraine Foundation (O4U) said in a media release.
Ukraine’s NovaPost has delivered the bread free of charge, “ensuring supplies reach even the hardest-hit areas,” it added.
O4U added that it was “proud” to support Chekerenda’s third annual ride.
“Food security remains one of the most urgent humanitarian challenges in Ukraine,” said Dr. Kate Woodman of O4U. “Bohdan’s ride shows how one person’s determination can spark generosity across an entire community — turning compassion into bread and hope.”
Black Press Media has reached out to O4U for a final count on how much was raised through the event.
